column1: LocationID,Place,Review,User

1,New York: EWR - Newark Airport,"Terrible if you have to change terminals. Still using a bus, which apparently can’t run in the rain, so potentially hours-long waits to change gates, with no seating or services in waiting area. Worst big US airport, in my experience.",Bocodude

2,New York: Queens - Jamaica Bay,"Even in central N.Y.C. you can still manage to see the unique natural setting with the coast, the islands and rivers nearby, out on Jamaica bay it is all much closer. You will find the sandy beaches/ wetland/ tidal basin sort of coast there...",Hoben01

3,New York: Bronx - Allerton/Pelham Gardens,"Pelham Gardens is a residential neighborhood with a longstanding community that is pretty centrally located. The Pelham Parkway is close by, you have big employers like the Jacobi Hospital and it's a safe area. Even though it's the Bronx, it feels more like a suburb.",Joe Cosentino

4,New York: Manhattan - Alphabet City,"Alphabet City feels like a true neighborhood, which can be hard to find in Manhattan. It's a blend of past and present with bars and restaurants abundant. Very nice area to walk around.",Lula N

5,New York: Staten Island - Arden Heights,"Arden Heights is home to many people from Staten Island. This suburban community is surrounded by revitalized natural spaces, including the Freshkills Park. A quiet bedroom community.",Anonymous
6,New York: Staten Island - Arrochar/Fort Wadsworth,"Beautiful views and cool history, but watch your step on some trails. A nice place to visit for family outings.",Michael S
7,New York: Queens - Astoria,"Astoria is a very nice neighborhood. It is safe, well-populated with good restaurants and parks, and has a distinct community feel.",Current Resident
8,New York: Queens - Astoria Park,"Astoria Park is my favorite park in Queens. Clean, spacious, with beautiful views and a great running track.",Kaylee M
9,New York: Queens - Auburndale,"No specific review found. Anonymous.",Anonymous
10,New York: Queens - Baisley Park,"No specific review found. Anonymous.",Anonymous
11,New York: Brooklyn - Bath Beach,"No specific review found. Anonymous.",Anonymous
12,New York: Manhattan - Battery Park,"No specific review found. Anonymous.",Anonymous
13,New York: Manhattan - Battery Park City,"No specific review found. Anonymous.",Anonymous
14,New York: Brooklyn - Bay Ridge,"No specific review found. Anonymous.",Anonymous
15,New York: Queens - Bay Terrace/Fort Totten,Beautiful location with bay views. Very family friendly and secure area.,Tmrbuddy31
16,New York: Queens - Bayside,Very peaceful and quiet place in the suburbs. Great for families and convenient transportation options.,Local Resident
17,New York: Brooklyn - Bedford,Bedford-Stuyvesant has a unique and lively character with a growing cultural scene.,Longtime Resident
18,New York: Bronx - Bedford Park,"A truly working-class oasis, peaceful and with good transportation.",Local New Yorker
19,New York: Queens - Bellerose,"Very safe and friendly neighborhood, with good schools and accessibility.",Neighborhood Fan
20,New York: Bronx - Belmont,Classic old-school Italian dining and welcoming community atmosphere.,Frank Franz
21,New York: Brooklyn - Bensonhurst East,"A diverse, quiet, and safe neighborhood with great Italian restaurants.",Neighborhood Watch
22,New York: Brooklyn - Bensonhurst West,Multicultural community with good amenities and access to transport.,Resident
23,New York: Staten Island - Bloomfield/Emerson Hill,Quiet suburban feel surrounded by natural spaces and parks.,Anonymous
24,New York: Manhattan - Bloomingdale,Upscale residential area with parks and close to cultural spots.,City Dweller
25,New York: Brooklyn - Boerum Hill,"Trendy neighborhood with boutiques, cafes and growing popularity.",Young Professional
26,New York: Brooklyn - Borough Park,Strong community feel with many religious and cultural institutions.,Local Member
27,New York: Queens - Breezy Point/Fort Tilden/Riis Beach,"Beautiful beaches and natural reserves, good for outdoor activities.",Visitor

28,New York: Queens - Briarwood/Jamaica Hills,"Briarwood is extremely welcoming and diverse, with great commuting options and a friendly community. The neighborhood features beautiful tree-lined streets and a mix of housing types. There are parks nearby and plenty of opportunities for all ages.",Anonymous [web:77]

29,New York: Brooklyn - Brighton Beach,"Brighton Beach is really the people's beach. The beach is generally clean, has changing rooms, and a pleasant boardwalk with great views of Coney Island. The sheltered water makes swimming safe for everyone.",P. Stuart C. [web:90]

30,New York: Queens - Broad Channel,"Broad Channel stands out as a tranquil island community in Jamaica Bay. Residents enjoy a relaxed, coastal atmosphere and proximity to the Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge, but the area faces the challenge of flood risk.",Anonymous [web:91]

31,New York: Bronx - Bronx Park,"Bronx Park offers a peaceful escape with plenty of nature and green spaces. It's a popular spot for locals who want to experience the outdoors in the city.",Anonymous [web:92][web:96]

32,New York: Bronx - Bronxdale,"All in all, Bronxdale is a safe, quiet, low-key neighborhood that is good for someone who wants the convenience of the Bronx, but not too much vibrance or energy.",Amelia [web:100]

33,New York: Brooklyn - Brooklyn Heights,"Brooklyn Heights is a beautiful and peaceful neighborhood. The restaurants are delicious and the bars are low key. You're steps from Brooklyn Bridge Park, which is a stunning place to relax and enjoy the Manhattan skyline.",Anonymous [web:102]

34,New York: Brooklyn - Brooklyn Navy Yard,"The Saturday-only guided walking tour provides an excellent overview of the Brooklyn Navy Yard's history and its current industrial usage. It's essential to go as part of a tour to see historic spots and current industrial operations.",Tripadvisor user [web:111]

35,New York: Brooklyn - Brownsville,"Brownsville is my home. As everyone can tell, Brownsville is not the safest, but it is full of culture and memories. There are many crimes, but once you don't bother anyone, they probably won't bother you.",Anonymous [web:104]

36,New York: Brooklyn - Bushwick North,"Bushwick is a family friendly neighborhood with lots of local restaurants, bars, and coffee shops. The area is very safe and welcoming, and there are often holiday decorations put up and celebrations happening.",Anonymous [web:105]

37,New York: Brooklyn - Bushwick South,"Bushwick has come a long way from the dark days of 1977, transforming to a vibrant community full of art and diversity. The original heart of Bushwick is still alive.",Rob Stephenson [web:114]

38,New York: Queens - Cambria Heights,"Cambria Heights is a wonderful neighborhood filled with solid schools and rich culture. It's safe, quiet, and offers a strong sense of community.",Anonymous [web:107]
39,New York: Brooklyn - Canarsie,"Canarsie Park is good. I recommend it. I've been here for family picnics. Predominantly West Indian, people keep the area clean and friendly.",Kalisha E. [web:108]

40,New York: Brooklyn - Carroll Gardens,"Carroll Gardens offers leafy streets, brownstones, and a friendly, welcoming community. The neighborhood is popular with families due to its parks and relaxed atmosphere.",Anonymous [web:116]

41,New York: Manhattan - Central Harlem,"Harlem is a vibrant neighborhood pulsating with culture and history. I loved the rich tapestry of art, music, and soul food that permeates its streets. The diversity of people fosters a sense of community. Wonderful food and nightlife.",Anonymous [web:127][web:132]

42,New York: Manhattan - Central Harlem North,"Central Harlem North is alive with history and culture. Gentrification brings new restaurants and boutiques alongside the classic Harlem brownstones. It's diverse, energetic, and a great place to experience authentic New York.",Anonymous [web:121][web:132]

43,New York: Manhattan - Central Park,"Central Park isn’t just a park, it truly feels like the heart of New York City. Every time I visit, I discover something new from the hidden bridges to the peaceful Ramble trails and the stunning views around Bethesda Terrace.",Jennifer W. [web:64][web:72]

44,New York: Staten Island - Charleston/Tottenville,"Tottenville is a quiet, suburban area on Staten Island. It’s peaceful, with good schools and parks, ideal for families or anyone seeking a slower pace in NYC.",Anonymous [web:123][web:128]

45,New York: Manhattan - Chinatown,"Chinatown is quite large and full of shops and authentic restaurants. It’s worth a visit for a different slice of New York life and delicious food. Great place to buy unique souvenirs.",Angelo D'Agostino [web:66]

46,New York: Bronx - City Island,"City Island has a nautical feel and great community. Fantastic seafood restaurants and peaceful waterfront views are its hallmarks, but expect traffic during peak times.",Jason M. [web:129]

47,New York: Bronx - Claremont/Bathgate,"Claremont is a vibrant, diverse neighborhood in the South Bronx. There’s plenty of green space, good transit, and a strong sense of community.",Anonymous [web:130]

48,New York: Manhattan - Clinton East,"Clinton East is melting pot of cultures with easy access to parks, great shops, and family-friendly vibes. There's a quiet charm among the classic city bustle.",Anonymous [web:126]

49,New York: Brooklyn - Clinton Hill,"Clinton Hill is a beautiful and diverse neighborhood known for brownstones, lively restaurants, and community events. It's safe, scenic, and has a creative vibe.",Anonymous

50,New York: Manhattan - Clinton West,"Clinton West, also known as Hell's Kitchen, offers a gritty but exciting New York experience. The neighborhood is packed with diverse restaurants, great nightlife, and convenient transport. It's vibrant, artsy, and ideal for young professionals, but can be crowded and noisy close to Times Square.",LisaAnnBurke [web:157]

51,New York: Bronx - Co-Op City,"Co-op City is a functioning community with affordable housing, plenty of amenities, and a city-within-a-city atmosphere. Despite its large population, it feels safe and well-kept, and most daily needs can be met within walking distance.",Anonymous [web:135][web:137][web:145]

52,New York: Brooklyn - Cobble Hill,"Cobble Hill is a very quaint, family-oriented neighborhood. Charming tree-lined streets, authentic restaurants, and a laid-back pace make it perfect for families and professionals. Plenty of good food and beautiful architecture.",Anonymous [web:138][web:146]

53,New York: Queens - College Point,"College Point is a peaceful, friendly, and safe neighborhood in Queens. It has quiet streets, scenic parks, and a strong sense of community, though transit to other parts of the city can be a challenge.",Anonymous [web:139][web:147]

54,New York: Brooklyn - Columbia Street,"Columbia Street Waterfront District is Brooklyn’s best-kept secret – quiet, scenic, and artistic, with beautiful waterfront views, indie shops, and a friendly, creative energy.",Anonymous [web:140][web:148]

55,New York: Brooklyn - Coney Island,"Coney Island is iconic and unique, with an old-school boardwalk, great food, rides, and a lively atmosphere. It's always a fun destination for families and people-watching.",Jack [web:141][web:149]

56,New York: Queens - Corona,"Corona is busy, diverse, and vibrant. The area is known for its Latin American restaurants and proximity to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. A true melting pot with lots to do and see.",Anonymous [web:142][web:150]
57,New York: Queens - Corona,"The Corona neighborhood offers great Latin eateries and parks. It's bustling and colorful, with a rich sense of community spirit.",Anonymous [web:142][web:150]

58,New York: Bronx - Country Club,"Country Club is quiet, safe, and family-friendly, with plenty of green spaces and a relaxed vibe. Residents praise its sense of community and well-kept environment.",Will M. [web:143][web:151]

59,New York: Bronx - Crotona Park,"Crotona Park is beloved for its large green spaces, historic features, and variety of recreational activities. It's a hub for community events and offers a natural oasis in the Bronx.",Anonymous [web:144][web:152]

60,New York: Bronx - Crotona Park East,"Crotona Park East is close to parks and playgrounds, with a growing sense of neighborhood identity. Residents value its convenience and improving amenities.",Anonymous [web:144][web:152]

61,New York: Brooklyn - Crown Heights North,"Crown Heights North is a vibrant area with plenty of shops, cafés, and leafy streets. It's diverse and energetic with excellent transport connections and a rich cultural mix.",Allan S [web:161][web:162][web:164]

62,New York: Brooklyn - Crown Heights South,"Crown Heights South blends classic brownstones and new developments. The area is diverse, dynamic, and feels like a true Brooklyn melting pot. Great for both families and young professionals.",Anonymous [web:164][web:165][web:166]

63,New York: Brooklyn - Cypress Hills,"Cypress Hills is lively and diverse, with great parks and friendly neighbors. Safe during the day, but some recommend extra caution at night. Housing is moderately affordable, and the area is improving.",Anonymous [web:167][web:175]

64,New York: Queens - Douglaston,"Douglaston is a wonderful neighborhood—safe, peaceful, and great for families. Schools are excellent and residents enjoy convenient transport and walkable parks.",Jennifer H. E. [web:168][web:176]

65,New York: Brooklyn - Downtown Brooklyn/MetroTech,"MetroTech in Downtown Brooklyn is transforming from an office park to a lively area with trendy cafés, cultural events, and revitalized green spaces—a recent $50 million renovation is changing the image of the area to feel much more welcoming.",Regina Myer [web:169][web:177]

66,New York: Brooklyn - DUMBO/Vinegar Hill,"Vinegar Hill House in DUMBO is a hidden gem with cozy dining and consistently excellent food. The neighborhood blends quiet historic streets and lively art scenes.",Sisterpv [web:170][web:178]

67,New York: Brooklyn - Dyker Heights,"Dyker Heights is calm, family-friendly, and famous for its holiday lights. It's very safe, with beautiful homes and a strong community spirit.",Anonymous [web:171][web:179]

68,New York: Manhattan - East Chelsea,"East Chelsea is convenient to transit, restaurants, and the Flatiron district. Recent development has brought new residential energy, making it more lively and accessible than ever.",Anonymous [web:172][web:180]

69,New York: Bronx - East Concourse/Concourse Village,"Concourse Village offers quick transit, quality schools, and green parks. It's an active Bronx neighborhood with a strong sense of community.",Anonymous [web:144]

70,New York: Queens - East Elmhurst,"East Elmhurst is quiet, residential, and convenient to LaGuardia. It's known for safe streets, active local organizations, and pride in the neighborhood.",Anonymous [web:168]

71,New York: Brooklyn - East Flatbush/Farragut,"East Flatbush is generally a safe, residential area with a strong Caribbean presence and good transport links. Quiet, friendly, and has great food options but some pockets can be less safe.",Anonymous [web:181][web:185]

72,New York: Brooklyn - East Flatbush/Remsen Village,"Remsen Village is tight-knit, diverse, and community-focused. Residents take pride in their quiet neighborhood with convenient parks and local businesses.",Anonymous [web:186]

73,New York: Queens - East Flushing,"East Flushing is overcrowded but diverse, with affordable housing and a good library. Convenient transport, lots of bars, but few restaurants—most locals go to Flushing for shopping and food.",GraceW [web:195][web:187]

74,New York: Manhattan - East Harlem North,"East Harlem North has affordable rents, bustling Latin and Italian communities, and plenty of local eateries. Cheaper than other Manhattan spots with an authentic neighborly spirit.",Anonymous [web:188][web:196]

75,New York: Manhattan - East Harlem South,"South Harlem is busy and interesting, with new shops and cultural activity. It's a lively area in transition but retains its historical charm.",Anonymous [web:197]

76,New York: Brooklyn - East New York,"East New York is lively and challenging, with a strong, diverse community. Residents highlight the resilience and support in the face of crime and economic hardship.",Anonymous [web:190][web:191]

77,New York: Brooklyn - East New York/Pennsylvania Avenue,"Living by Pennsylvania Avenue gives easy access to shopping and transit. The area is improving, but opinions on safety are mixed. Many local businesses and housing options.",Anonymous [web:199]

78,New York: Bronx - East Tremont,"East Tremont is known for affordable rentals, good access to dining and transit, and a mix of urban convenience and quiet parks. Diverse, safe, with plenty to explore nearby.",Matthew Bank [web:192][web:200]
79,New York: Manhattan - East Village,"The East Village is creative, energetic, and full of character. Famous for its nightlife, quirky shops, murals, and strong cultural scene.",Anonymous [web:188]

80,New York: Brooklyn - East Williamsburg,"East Williamsburg is up-and-coming, known for vibrant art, nightlife, and industrial-loft style living. It mixes new residents and long-time locals—lively, walkable, and safe.",Anonymous [web:179]

81,New York: Bronx - Eastchester,"Eastchester is a great safe place to raise your family. It has low crime and a tight-knit community. Schools and parks are excellent, making it ideal for families. Some find it pricey but worth it for the quality of life.",Anonymous [web:201][web:202][web:203]

82,New York: Queens - Elmhurst,"Elmhurst is incredibly diverse with a rich mix of cultures and tasty ethnic food options. Convenient access to transportation and shopping centers makes it vibrant but somewhat congested.",Anonymous [web:206][web:214]

83,New York: Queens - Elmhurst/Maspeth,"Maspeth is calm, family-friendly, and offers a blend of residential and industrial areas. There are many community events and decent local services, with affordable housing compared to nearby areas.",Anonymous [web:207][web:215]

84,New York: Staten Island - Eltingville/Annadale/Prince's Bay,"Annadale and nearby Staten Island neighborhoods are quiet and safe with good schools and parks. Residents enjoy a suburban feel with easy access to shopping and transportation, but commuting can be slow.",Resident [web:208][web:216]

85,New York: Brooklyn - Erasmus,"High School for Service & Learning at Erasmus has supportive teachers and a strong community. The school encourages college readiness and offers many advanced classes, fostering a positive learning environment.",Student [web:209]

86,New York: Queens - Far Rockaway,"Far Rockaway is a charming coastal neighborhood with nice beaches and a family friendly vibe. There are challenges like higher crime and some underdevelopment, but community spirit remains strong.",Resident [web:210][web:218]

87,New York: Manhattan - Financial District North,"The Financial District is the heart of NYC’s business scene, with landmarks, museums, and great waterfront parks. It has good public transit, a vibrant restaurant scene, and is increasingly a lively residential area.",Anonymous [web:211][web:212][web:219][web:220]

88,New York: Manhattan - Financial District South,"The southern tip of the Financial District features historic sites like the 9/11 Memorial and Trinity Church, combined with modern skyscrapers and cultural venues. It's quieter in evenings but full of life during the day.",Anonymous [web:211][web:212]

89,New York: Brooklyn - Flatbush/Ditmas Park,"Ditmas Park is known for its beautiful Victorian homes and tree-lined streets. It has a relaxed neighborhood feel, a strong community, and flourishing local businesses.",Anonymous [web:144]

90,New York: Manhattan - Flatiron,"Flatiron is vibrant with iconic architecture, popular restaurants, and quick access to Union Square. It buzzes with energy, events, and offers great shopping options.",Anonymous [web:72]

91,New York: Brooklyn - Flatlands,"Flatlands is quiet and peaceful, great for families and retirees. It's suburban, with well-kept parks and accessible shopping. Parties and neighbor gatherings happen in summer; otherwise, it's calm and safe.",Anonymous [web:222]

92,New York: Queens - Flushing,"Flushing is an energetic, diverse neighborhood—a food lover's paradise with incredible Asian cuisine, vibrant markets, and easy access via the 7 train. The only downside is congestion and occasional untidy streets.",Anonymous [web:226]

93,New York: Queens - Flushing Meadows-Corona Park,"Flushing Meadows Corona Park is a living monument to NYC's multicultural spirit. The Unisphere, Queens Museum, and vibrant festivals stand out, but some say upkeep could be better.",maciek macak [web:227]

94,New York: Bronx - Fordham South,"Fordham South is one of the Bronx's densest neighborhoods, offering historic architecture, robust bike lanes, and a lively street scene. Mixed ratings for schools, solid transit, and a diverse community.",Anonymous [web:228]

95,New York: Queens - Forest Hills,"Forest Hills is safe, convenient, and beautiful—a hidden gem packed with parks, great food, and excellent schools. Nightlife is busy, neighbors friendly, but subway stations could use improvement.",Anonymous [web:229]

96,New York: Queens - Forest Park/Highland Park,"Forest Park is a peaceful, wooded area—ideal for long walks, picnics, and mountain biking. Unique trails make exploration fun for all ages, and the carousel is a family favorite.",Marie [web:230][web:238]

97,New York: Brooklyn - Fort Greene,"Fort Greene is diverse, artsy, and walkable. Beautiful brownstone streets, amazing food, a family friendly feel, and outstanding access to subways—one of Brooklyn's most charming neighborhoods.",Anonymous [web:239][web:231]
98,New York: Queens - Fresh Meadows,"Fresh Meadows is quiet and child-friendly, with plenty of green spaces for recreation. The community values good schools and relaxed living.",Anonymous [web:240]

99,New York: Staten Island - Freshkills Park,"Freshkills Park is an ambitious project transforming landfill into green public spaces. Trails, nature programs, and unique events are making it popular, but parts remain under construction.",Anonymous [web:99]

100,New York: Manhattan - Garment District,"The Garment District is bustling with fabric shops, fashion studios, and food spots—great for shopping and people-watching, but crowded and noisy during peak hours.",Anonymous [web:72]

101,New York: Queens - Glen Oaks,"Glen Oaks is very quiet and safe, with friendly neighbors and plenty of stores nearby. The school district is excellent, making it ideal for families. It's peaceful, dog-friendly, and has lots of parks and local events.",Anonymous [web:242]

102,New York: Queens - Glendale,"Glendale offers suburban vibes and clean streets, with big shopping centers and German restaurants. It's quiet and popular with families due to many schools and a competitive price point for homes.",Andrew LaSala [web:246][web:254]

103,New York: Manhattan - Governor's Island/Ellis Island/Liberty Island,"Governors Island is a perfect place for a sunny day—historic army buildings, art exhibitions, playgrounds, beer gardens, and amazing skyline views. The short ferry ride adds fun.",Tanisha [web:247][web:255]

104,New York: Manhattan - Governor's Island/Ellis Island/Liberty Island,"Ellis Island offers a deeply moving museum experience that makes you reflect on America's immigrant history. Free audio guides add to the thoughtful exhibitions.",Angelo D'Agostino [web:256][web:257]

105,New York: Manhattan - Governor's Island/Ellis Island/Liberty Island,"Liberty Island delivers iconic views of Lady Liberty and Manhattan. Early morning visits are best; the museum is very informative, but it gets crowded. Climbing the Crown is worth it if possible.",Charles_and_Susan [web:249]

106,New York: Brooklyn - Gowanus,"Gowanus is family-friendly, artsy, and full of great food spots. It’s walkable with parks nearby and new developments bringing even more energy. Some areas by the canal can be less pleasant.",Anonymous [web:250][web:258]

107,New York: Manhattan - Gramercy,"Gramercy Park is exclusive, elegant, and tranquil—tree-lined streets, brownstones, and genteel charm. Most negatives are only out of envy; it's very expensive but perfect for professionals and families.",Anonymous [web:251][web:259]

108,New York: Brooklyn - Gravesend,"Gravesend is peaceful and conveniently located with easy transit and supermarkets. It used to be cleaner, but some landmark eateries remain. Diverse residents and generally a sense of safety.",Anonymous [web:252]

109,New York: Staten Island - Great Kills,"Great Kills is a safe, family-focused neighborhood with parks, marinas, and good schools, making it popular for families and retirees wanting community and outdoor activities.",Anonymous [web:253]
110,New York: Staten Island - Great Kills Park,"Great Kills Park features wetlands, woodlands, and beaches with lots of space for walking",Anonymous [web:356]

111,New York: Brooklyn - Green-Wood Cemetery,"Green-Wood Cemetery is a stunning, historic site with 500 acres of beautiful landscaping, famous tombs, art exhibits, and scenic views of Manhattan. It's peaceful and popular for guided walks and history tours.",Itinerant_Foodies [web:261]

112,New York: Brooklyn - Greenpoint,"Greenpoint offers a quiet, family-friendly vibe, amazing food, excellent parks, and a strong sense of local community. The only real downside is reliance on the G train, but everything else makes it charming and desirable.",Anonymous [web:266]

113,New York: Manhattan - Greenwich Village North,"Greenwich Village is packed with history, bohemian spirit, great theaters, coffee shops, and music venues. Its welcoming neighborhood feel and lively street life make it a favorite among artists and students.",Anonymous [web:267][web:268][web:276]

114,New York: Manhattan - Greenwich Village South,"The southern end of Greenwich Village boasts iconic sights, beautiful architecture, and energetic nightlife. Residents enjoy leafy streets and a vibrant mix of cultures, restaurants, and boutique shops.",Anonymous [web:275][web:268]

115,New York: Staten Island - Grymes Hill/Clifton,"Grymes Hill is one of Staten Island’s safest and most beautiful areas, with historic homes, sweeping views of Manhattan, and a diverse local community. Clifton adds a scholarly vibe and college town feel.",Lauren Levert [web:269][web:277]

116,New York: Manhattan - Hamilton Heights,"Hamilton Heights is historic, diverse, and affordable, with stunning riverside views, elegant brownstones, parks, and a strong sense of community. It attracts students, families, and creative professionals.",Anonymous [web:270][web:278]

117,New York: Queens - Hammels/Arverne,"Arverne is a tight-knit coastal neighborhood famous for Caribbean eateries, surfing spots, and a welcoming, multicultural community. Gentrification is slowly bringing new businesses and cafes.",Anonymous [web:271][web:279]

118,New York: Staten Island - Heartland Village/Todt Hill,"Heartland Village is family-focused, suburban, and full of parks, schools, and local shops. Todt Hill stands out for its quiet streets and scenic value. Both offer tranquility and a strong community atmosphere.",Anonymous [web:272][web:280]

119,New York: Bronx - Highbridge,"Highbridge is a diverse neighborhood with great views, improving schools, access to High Bridge Park, and a vibrant Latino community. Housing is affordable, and there’s a strong neighborhood identity.",Anonymous [web:144]

120,New York: Manhattan - Highbridge Park,"Highbridge Park stretches along the Harlem River with miles of trails, sports courts, wooded areas, and playgrounds. It's a popular spot for outdoor activities and scenic walks.",Anonymous [web:144]

121,New York: Queens - Hillcrest/Pomonok,"Hillcrest and Pomonok are quiet, residential neighborhoods. Hillcrest feels like a college town in Queens, and Pomonok offers historic charm and well-rated schools. Both have a strong local community and easy access to public transit.",Anonymous [web:281][web:282][web:284]

122,New York: Queens - Hollis,"Hollis is diverse, welcoming, and has everything you need close by—grocery stores, restaurants, and good public transportation. The community is clean and caring, but some want increased public safety.",Anonymous [web:286]

123,New York: Brooklyn - Homecrest,"Homecrest is a peaceful and diverse residential neighborhood, popular with families and older residents. It's known for its vibrant community, Avenue U shops, and affordable living. Not a party scene, but safe and convenient.",Anonymous [web:287][web:295]

124,New York: Queens - Howard Beach,"Howard Beach is a friendly, safe, and pet-friendly neighborhood. There's a strong sense of community with clean parks, lots of local stores, and good transportation connections. Quiet and welcoming, but parking can be tough.",Anonymous [web:288][web:296]

125,New York: Manhattan - Hudson Sq,"Hudson Square combines historic charm with new developments. It's central, walkable, near the Hudson River, and is gaining popularity for office and residential life thanks to parks and lots of transit options.",Jesse Luo [web:289][web:297]

126,New York: Bronx - Hunts Point,"Hunts Point is convenient, urban, and full of restaurants and markets. The area is diverse and active, but has ongoing challenges with safety and traffic. Residents emphasize the strong sense of community and resilience.",Anonymous [web:290][web:298]

127,New York: Manhattan - Inwood,"Inwood is famously diverse, affordable, and loaded with parks. It’s safe, lively, and a great place for families or those wanting direct subway access and a neighborhood feel. There are lots of restaurants, Latin and Irish bars, and community events.",Anonymous [web:291][web:299]

128,New York: Manhattan - Inwood Hill Park,"Inwood Hill Park is one of Manhattan’s most natural spaces, with forests, marshland, trails, and historic caves. Locals love it for peaceful walks, river vistas, and a break from the city’s pace.",Justin W. [web:292][web:300]

129,New York: Queens - Jackson Heights,"Jackson Heights is a vibrant, multicultural neighborhood with amazing global dining, thriving small businesses, and historic buildings. The subway gets crowded, but the atmosphere is friendly and lively.",Anonymous [web:226]

130,New York: Queens - Jamaica,"Jamaica, Queens, is a busy, central neighborhood full of shopping, transit, and global cuisine. It's diverse and energetic—good for convenience, but can be noisy and fast-paced.",Jennifer V. [web:293]

131,New York: Queens - Jamaica Estates,"Jamaica Estates is quiet, beautiful, and full of historic homes and trees. It’s diverse and very family-friendly—a great place to grow up, with convenient transit and shopping. The community is safe and welcoming.",Anonymous [web:301][web:303][web:312]

132,New York: Queens - JFK Airport,"JFK Airport is conveniently located and has lots of transit options. International travelers appreciate its variety of dining spots but dislike long lines and sometimes slow baggage handling.",Anonymous [web:305][web:313]

133,New York: Brooklyn - Kensington,"Kensington is calm, diverse, and perfect for families seeking quiet living in Brooklyn. There’s great halal food, good schools, and a mix of leafy streets and busy avenues.",Anonymous [web:306][web:314]

134,New York: Queens - Kew Gardens,"Kew Gardens is green, quiet, and full of historic charm. Residents enjoy good parks, a mix of cultures, and strong community ties, although parking can be challenging.",Anonymous [web:315][web:316]

135,New York: Queens - Kew Gardens Hills,"Kew Gardens Hills stands out for safety, excellent schools, and tree-lined blocks. The area is diverse, with easy access to transit, shopping, and beautiful parks.",Anonymous [web:307][web:308][web:315]

136,New York: Bronx - Kingsbridge Heights,"Kingsbridge Heights is safe, diverse, and convenient, with great parks, restaurants, and easy transit. Locals highlight the neighborhood’s strong sense of community—even though some areas feel sketchy at night, it’s still a welcoming spot.",Anonymous [web:317]

137,New York: Manhattan - Kips Bay,"Kips Bay is modern, convenient, and friendly. There’s good dining, easy commutes, and a mix of new development and older charm. Residents praise its location and walkability, but wish it had more nightlife options.",Anonymous [web:318]

138,New York: Queens - LaGuardia Airport,"LaGuardia Airport is convenient for domestic flights, offers quick check-ins and free shuttles, but can get crowded and lacks enough dining options. Renovations improved the terminal experience.",Rosemarie [web:311][web:319]

139,New York: Queens - Laurelton,"Laurelton is known for neat lawns, classic homes, quiet and friendly neighbors, and strong middle-class vibes. It’s walkable, green, and popular with families.",Anonymous [web:226]

140,New York: Manhattan - Lenox Hill East,"Lenox Hill East is upscale, safe, and close to Central Park and Museum Mile. Residents enjoy walkable streets, great shopping, and easy subway access.",Anonymous [web:275]

141,New York: Manhattan - Lenox Hill West,"Lenox Hill West blends upscale city living with classic New York charm. Easy access to Central Park, museums, and elegant shops—the neighborhood is neighborly, clean, and family friendly, but pricey!",Anonymous [web:321][web:322][web:332]

142,New York: Manhattan - Lincoln Square East,"Lincoln Square East is central, safe, and full of cultural venues—Lincoln Center, great shopping, and proximity to Central Park. Many older residents and families, clean and calm but a bit lacking youthful energy.",tantricstrawberry [web:325][web:333]

143,New York: Manhattan - Lincoln Square West,"Lincoln Square West is a tourist-friendly spot with entertainment, restaurants, and quiet residential areas close to the action. Residents enjoy access to outdoor spaces and transit.",Anonymous [web:326][web:334]

144,New York: Manhattan - Little Italy/NoLiTa,"Little Italy and NoLiTa are lively and trendy. Great food, chic shops, art galleries, and cozy cafés, all in a walkable, picturesque district. Can be crowded during festivals, but it’s a must-see NYC experience.",Neta_Avivi [web:327][web:335]

145,New York: Queens - Long Island City/Hunters Point,"Long Island City and Hunters Point are safe, walkable, and popular among young professionals. Excellent parks, beautiful skyline views, and abundant dining options in this rapidly developing waterfront area.",Anonymous [web:336][web:328]

146,New York: Queens - Long Island City/Queens Plaza,"Queens Plaza offers an affordable, convenient location with easy transit and modern apartments. Some buildings have slow elevators but most residents enjoy the commute and amenities.",marco c. [web:337][web:329]

147,New York: Bronx - Longwood,"Longwood is diverse, full of historic architecture and culture. Residents praise the vibrant art scene, local shops, and welcoming community, but note crime rates need improvement.",Anonymous [web:330][web:338]

148,New York: Manhattan - Lower East Side,"The Lower East Side is eclectic, energetic, and full of nightlife. Street art, unique restaurants, galleries, and music venues create a lively, walkable vibe—though cleanliness and affordability are ongoing challenges.",Anonymous [web:331][web:339]

149,New York: Brooklyn - Madison,"Madison is a classic Brooklyn neighborhood known for tree-lined streets, bakeries, Jewish delis, and a low-key, neighborly feel—safe and popular for families seeking suburban peace in the city.",Anonymous [web:144]

150,New York: Brooklyn - Manhattan Beach,"Manhattan Beach is quiet, safe, and full of beautiful homes. Residents appreciate its exclusive feel, easy access to the boardwalk and park, and strong community spirit.",Anonymous [web:144]

151,New York: Manhattan - Manhattan Valley,"Manhattan Valley is a hidden gem. It’s diverse, creative, close to Central Park, and still affordable for the Upper West Side. Neighbors are friendly and look out for each other, and there are great restaurants and cozy streets.",Anonymous [web:341][web:342][web:343]

152,New York: Manhattan - Manhattanville,"Manhattanville is convenient—easy subway access, close to City College and Morningside Park. Diverse, with a mix of students and families, and some cool food spots.",Anonymous [web:353]

153,New York: Manhattan - Marble Hill,"Marble Hill is urban, safe, and affordable, with many friendly people and plenty of stores. It's great for dog walkers and families, though rent can be expensive. A quiet neighborhood with good police presence.",Jennifer R. [web:346][web:354]

154,New York: Brooklyn - Marine Park/Floyd Bennett Field,"Marine Park and Floyd Bennett Field are family-friendly and loaded with green space for picnics, biking, and sports. The field itself is historically fascinating and hosts lots of recreation.",Paul S [web:347][web:355][web:356]

155,New York: Brooklyn - Marine Park/Mill Basin,"Marine Park feels genuine and welcoming, great for families and outdoor activities. Mill Basin is more upscale, secluded, and features architecturally unique homes. Bus service is good; train access is limited.",Zultan27 [web:356][web:348]

156,New York: Staten Island - Mariners Harbor,"Mariners Harbor is affordable and diverse, rich in history and waterfront recreation. There are great parks, friendly locals, and convenient access anywhere by car or bus.",Anonymous [web:349][web:357]

157,New York: Queens - Maspeth,"Maspeth blends city living with suburban peace. Rich history, diverse community, parks and green spaces, family businesses, and quiet streets make it charming for all ages.",Anonymous [web:358][web:350]

158,New York: Manhattan - Meatpacking/West Village West,"Meatpacking/West Village is trendy, vibrant, and packed with eclectic shops, nightlife, and art. The High Line, galleries, and restaurants attract crowds—come for people-watching and urban adventure.",therichastill [web:351][web:359]

159,New York: Bronx - Melrose South,"Melrose South is lively and urban with affordable rentals, easy shopping, decent parks, and direct transit access. It’s rapidly changing thanks to development, but retains a strong sense of community.",Anonymous [web:144]

160,New York: Queens - Middle Village,"Middle Village is peaceful, suburban, and perfect for families. Clean streets, well-kept homes, low crime, and friendly neighborhood feel make life comfortable.",Anonymous [web:144]

161,New York: Manhattan - Midtown Center,"Midtown Center is the heart of Manhattan: everything is accessible, with iconic landmarks, luxury shopping, and busy nightlife. It's ideal for tourists and professionals but crowded and expensive.",Anonymous [web:363][web:364]

162,New York: Manhattan - Midtown East,"Midtown East is quiet, safe, central, and perfect for professionals. Walking distance to work, good restaurants, a peaceful vibe, and great transport—less trendy, but a very practical neighborhood.",Anonymous [web:365][web:373]

163,New York: Manhattan - Midtown North,"Midtown North features stunning skyscrapers, immersive walking tours, and classic NYC energy. The area is very convenient, bustling during weekdays, and great for architecture lovers.",Anonymous [web:366][web:374]

164,New York: Manhattan - Midtown South,"Midtown South is lively, central, and full of major attractions. Great for shopping, quick commutes, entertainment, and nightlife, but it's always busy.",Leonard Inzirillo [web:367][web:375]

165,New York: Brooklyn - Midwood,"Midwood is safe, clean, and community-oriented, with great bakeries, grocery stores, schools, and a rich Hasidic Jewish presence. Convenient but a bit out of the way for transit; friendly people.",Anonymous [web:368][web:376]

166,New York: Manhattan - Morningside Heights,"Morningside Heights is quiet, academic, and peaceful—stunning architecture, three parks, and access to Columbia University. It’s calm but diverse, with lots of cafes and culture.",Anonymous [web:369][web:377]

167,New York: Bronx - Morrisania/Melrose,"Morrisania/Melrose is affordable and diverse, lots of transit and new buildings, but public safety can vary. Strong community pride and plenty of cultural heritage.",Anonymous [web:370][web:378]

168,New York: Bronx - Mott Haven/Port Morris,"Mott Haven/Port Morris is diverse and resilient, undergoing revitalization with new waterfront parks and strong community engagement. Historic charm, cultural energy, and ongoing improvements.",Anonymous [web:371][web:379]
169,New York: Bronx - Mount Hope,"Mount Hope is friendly and improving, known for good schools, new parks, solid transport, and a growing sense of local identity.",Anonymous [web:144]

170,New York: Manhattan - Murray Hill,"Murray Hill is convenient, walkable, and popular with young professionals. Lots of bars, restaurants, and city buzz—can be noisy at night but always lively.",Anonymous [web:318]

171,New York: Queens - Murray Hill-Queens,"Murray Hill in Queens is quiet and a commuter’s haven with lots of Korean restaurants and small shops near the LIRR station. Great for foodies, but safety and parking can be issues for residents.",Anonymous [web:381][web:382]

172,New York: Staten Island - New Dorp/Midland Beach,"New Dorp and Midland Beach are peaceful, family-friendly neighborhoods with lots of boardwalk, soft sand, and open beachfront. Ideal for long walks, recreation, and beachcombing—just bring your own food.",Danielle G. [web:385][web:393]

173,New York: Queens - North Corona,"North Corona is one of the most densely populated and vibrant neighborhoods in Queens. Diverse cuisine, lots of public transport connections, and easy access to parks—busy, energetic, and friendly.",Anthony Tamboni [web:386][web:394]

174,New York: Bronx - Norwood,"Norwood is a vibrant, family-oriented community with tree-lined streets, parks, and a relaxed vibe. Transport is great, but there are some building issues—friendly neighbors and a suburban feel in the Bronx.",Anonymous [web:387][web:395]

175,New York: Queens - Oakland Gardens,"Oakland Gardens is quiet, safe, walkable, and filled with parks and good schools. Neighbors are friendly and amenities are close by; the area feels suburban and family-friendly.",Leslie F. [web:388][web:396]

176,New York: Staten Island - Oakwood,"Oakwood has a country-in-the-city charm with winding streets, friendly neighbors, and quick access to the beach, shopping, and transit. Well-loved for safety and a family feel.",Adnan S. [web:389][web:397]

177,New York: Brooklyn - Ocean Hill,"Ocean Hill is affordable and improving, with plenty of space, solid community amenities, and good access to subway lines. The area is seeing new investment and development.",Mark Martov [web:390][web:398]

178,New York: Brooklyn - Ocean Parkway South,"Ocean Parkway South is green and walkable, with park-like walkways, easy access for both cars and bikes, and plenty of local shops. A leafy, pleasant route for commuting in Brooklyn.",Duane S. [web:391][web:399]

179,New York: Queens - Old Astoria,"Old Astoria has historic charm, growing arts and dining scenes, riverfront parks, and stellar skyline views. It’s quiet, diverse, and on the rise with convenient access to Manhattan.",Anonymous [web:226]

180,New York: Queens - Ozone Park,"Ozone Park has a suburban vibe, multicultural food options, and friendly neighbors. Quick commutes to Brooklyn and JFK, safe streets, and a good selection of schools and stores.",Anonymous [web:226]

181,New York: Brooklyn - Park Slope,"Park Slope is a beautiful, safe, and family-friendly Brooklyn neighborhood. It's full of brownstones, trees, great schools, trendy restaurants, and sits next to Prospect Park—perfect for families and outdoor lovers. It can be pricey and crowded, but the quality of life is hard to beat.",Anonymous [web:401][web:402][web:403]

182,New York: Bronx - Parkchester,"Parkchester is diverse and welcoming, with plenty of shops, restaurants, and transit options. Neighbors look out for one another, making the community great for families. Beautiful buildings and lots of green space.",Anonymous [web:405][web:413]

183,New York: Bronx - Pelham Bay,"Pelham Bay is a quiet, safe Bronx neighborhood with a strong community and good parks. There's a small-town feel, convenient shopping, and it's close to Pelham Bay Park and Orchard Beach.",Anonymous [web:406]

184,New York: Bronx - Pelham Bay Park,"Pelham Bay Park is the city's largest park. It offers serene natural spaces, tennis courts, playgrounds, and a beach. Great for birdwatching, dog walks, and family outings any season.",Kathleen Y. [web:407][web:415]

185,New York: Bronx - Pelham Parkway,"Pelham Parkway is leafy, residential, and middle-class. The community blends apartment buildings and houses; it's a good place to own, has strong transit, and offers easy access to schools and shopping.",Maria Capotorto [web:408][web:414][web:416]

186,New York: Manhattan - Penn Station/Madison Sq West,"Penn Station is iconic and chaotic but functional. It's always crowded, with construction ongoing, but offers good transport links and food options. The area is busy day and night due to Madison Square Garden events.",Nomad [web:409][web:417]

187,New York: Staten Island - Port Richmond,"Port Richmond is urban and suburban, rich in history, and close to the water and ferries. Access to stores and highways is good—there's a strong sense of local identity, but some areas can be industrial.",Angela M. [web:410][web:418]

188,New York: Brooklyn - Prospect-Lefferts Gardens,"Prospect-Lefferts Gardens is stunning and community-oriented. Close to Prospect Park, it offers diversity, bistros, coffee shops, and beautiful old houses, although it can feel crowded and noisy at night.",Anonymous [web:411][web:419]

189,New York: Brooklyn - Prospect Heights,"Prospect Heights is vibrant, with good food, bars, brownstones, and easy access to Prospect Park and Barclays Center. Diverse and creative, but more affordable than nearby neighborhoods.",Anonymous [web:411]

190,New York: Brooklyn - Prospect Park,"Prospect Park is Brooklyn’s backyard—iconic for running, biking, picnics, and year-round events. It’s huge, green, and always full of life, with a rich mix of people and activities.",Anonymous [web:411]

191,New York: Queens - Queens Village,"Queens Village is diverse, friendly, and ideal for people seeking a quiet, relatively safe NYC neighborhood. 192,New York: Queens - Queensboro Hill,"Queensboro Hill is calm and leafy with good access to parks, diverse local food, and reliable transit. Limited nightlife, but great for families and those who love green spaces. Parking and traffic can be challenges.",Anonymous [web:425][web:433]

193,New York: Queens - Queensbridge/Ravenswood,"Queensbridge Park is beautiful, with amazing views of Manhattan and lots of lawn space, but the surrounding area can be noisy and less safe at night. Come for concerts, fireworks, and waterfront walks.",Jason P. [web:426][web:434]

194,New York: Manhattan - Randalls Island,"Randall’s Island Park is gorgeous and expansive, great for recreation, festivals, sports, and walking trails. Stunning views, though bathrooms and water fountains can be lacking during big events.",Jamila C. [web:427][web:435]

195,New York: Brooklyn - Red Hook,"Red Hook is industrial, creative, and known for local businesses and a waterfront vibe. It’s affordable for now, has great food and a community spirit, but safety and transport can be uneven.",Anonymous [web:428][web:436]

196,New York: Queens - Rego Park,"Rego Park is diverse and vibrant, with great food, shopping, and subway access. Good for families and retirees, though parking is challenging. The community is friendly and amenities abound.",Anonymous [web:429][web:437]

197,New York: Queens - Richmond Hill,"Richmond Hill is highly diverse, historic, and welcoming, with Indo-Caribbean cuisine, Victorian homes, religious diversity, and great park access. Housing remains affordable and the sense of community is strong.",Chatter Singh [web:430][web:438]

198,New York: Queens - Ridgewood,"Ridgewood is clean, very safe, and packed with shops and restaurants. It is walkable, multicultural, and has every amenity. Rents are rising, but the neighborhood’s spirit and accessibility remain.",Anonymous [web:439][web:431]

201,New York: Queens - Rockaway Park,"Rockaway Park is a comfortable place to be—close to the beach with a fantastic community atmosphere where neighbors look out for each other. Quiet, diverse, and with lots of local events and summer activities for families.",Anonymous [web:442][web:441]

202,New York: Manhattan - Roosevelt Island,"Roosevelt Island is quiet, scenic, with stunning skyline views and parks. There’s a small, friendly community—easy tram access to Manhattan, but fewer restaurants and nightlife compared to other neighborhoods.",Dianne S. [web:444][web:452]

204,New York: Staten Island - Rossville/Woodrow,"Rossville and Woodrow are quiet, spacious, with many parks and a strong community feel—ideal for families. Both are car-dependent but offer good schools and new developments.",Anonymous [web:446]

208,New York: Bronx - Schuylerville/Edgewater Park,"Schuylerville and Edgewater Park are quiet, residential, and walkable with a suburban vibe. Neighbors look out for each other, kids bike to parks, and the area is affordable and convenient to transit.",Niche User [web:450][web:458]

209,New York: Manhattan - Seaport,"The Seaport area is historic, lively, and features cobblestone streets, cultural events, dining, and great views along the East River. It’s touristy but full of character and fun in summer.",Anonymous [web:144]

221,New York: Staten Island - Stapleton,"Stapleton is a historic Staten Island neighborhood with Victorian homes, walkable waterfront, affordable rents, and a growing number of restaurants and new developments. 224,New York: Manhattan - Stuy Town/Peter Cooper Village,"Stuy Town is spacious, green, and kid-friendly, with good security and amenities. There are parks, playgrounds, and a close-knit community, though the management gets mixed reviews.",M Howard [web:484][web:492]

226,New York: Queens - Sunnyside,"Sunnyside is diverse, welcoming, and has a close-knit, small-town feel. There are great restaurants, parks, events, and excellent transit, but parking can be a challenge. Very safe and ideal for families.",Anonymous [web:494]

228,New York: Brooklyn - Sunset Park West,"Sunset Park West is green, diverse, and famous for views of Manhattan and summer events. It’s friendly and active, popular with families, and loved for its park amenities.",helloaaron23 [web:495][web:487]

230,New York: Manhattan - Times Sq/Theatre District,"Times Square and the Theatre District are iconic, lively, and never sleep. Every night is full of excitement, lights, shows, and tons of tourists. It's the heartbeat of NYC, but also crowded, noisy, and energetic 24/7.",Anonymous [web:144]

231,New York: Manhattan - TriBeCa/Civic Center,"TriBeCa and Civic Center are central, safe, and packed with NYC government buildings, law offices, high-end dining, street art, and galleries. Families, professionals, and creatives love the neighborhood vibe.",Anonymous [web:497][web:500]

234,New York: Manhattan - Union Sq,"Union Square is bustling, always full of activity, and a hub for markets, protests, and public art. Vendors, good transit, and events make this a classic NYC destination at all hours.",MariB [web:504][web:512]

235,New York: Bronx - University Heights/Morris Heights,"University Heights/Morris Heights are convenient, culturally diverse, and have strong transit, schools, and parks. Affordable for students and families but can get noisy around the university.",Anonymous [web:513][web:505]

236,New York: Manhattan - Upper East Side North,"The Upper East Side North is quiet, elegant, and known for leafy streets, historic buildings, Museum Mile, high-end shops, and proximity to Central Park. It’s classic old New York.",Thomas V. [web:506][web:507][web:515]

237,New York: Manhattan - Upper East Side South,"Upper East Side South is swanky, filled with luxury apartments, fine dining, and museums. Residents love the parks and river walks, but nightlife is limited: culture and shopping take center stage.",CaptainTrips [web:506][web:507]

238,New York: Manhattan - Upper West Side North,"Upper West Side North has a strong neighborhood feel, friendly families, prewar buildings, top-rated schools, cozy cafés, and easy park access. It’s both residential and vibrant.",Kristen P. [web:508][web:516]

239,New York: Manhattan - Upper West Side South,"Upper West Side South is classic, home to Lincoln Center, arts venues, shops, and beautiful brownstones. Count on lively streets, great food, active parks, and prime subway access.",Hayley K. [web:508][web:516]

240,New York: Bronx - Van Cortlandt Park,"Van Cortlandt Park is one of NYC’s largest, a green oasis with trails, sports fields, horseback riding, and a peaceful atmosphere for nature lovers in the Bronx.",Anonymous [web:144]

241,New York: Bronx - Van Cortlandt Village,"Van Cortlandt Village is quiet, friendly, and affordable for families or retirees. It is walkable, filled with parks, and has strong community vibes close to Van Cortlandt Park.",Anonymous [web:519][web:529]

242,New York: Bronx - Van Nest/Morris Park,"Van Nest/Morris Park is diverse, safe, and lively. The area has excellent bakeries, green spaces, and easy subway/bus access. Residents find it neighborly and welcoming for families.",Maria [web:530][web:522]

243,New York: Manhattan - Washington Heights North,"Washington Heights North is lively, energetic, and distinctly Latinx. There's a strong community, lots of restaurants and affordable housing, many train options and outstanding parks, but it can be noisy.",Samantha R [web:523][web:531][web:524]

244,New York: Manhattan - Washington Heights South,"Washington Heights South has beautiful Hudson River views, historic buildings, supportive neighbors, extensive Latin American culture, and offers affordable rents compared to other Manhattan neighborhoods.",Anonymous [web:524][web:532]

247,New York: Bronx - West Concourse,"West Concourse offers great subway access and proximity to Yankee Stadium, but is noisy and has ongoing safety concerns. Apartments are nice but management and neighborhood can be challenging.",Anonymous [web:535][web:527]

249,New York: Manhattan - West Village,"The West Village is charming, trendy, and famous for winding streets, LGBT+ history, cafés, and boutiques. Quiet homes mix with lively nightlife, making it a top Manhattan destination for culture and people-watching.",Anonymous [web:144]

251,New York: Staten Island - Westerleigh,"Westerleigh is one of Staten Island's safest and most charming neighborhoods. Beautiful old homes, tree-lined streets, walkability, great parks, and a real sense of community. Friendly for families and pets.",Anonymous [web:537][web:539][web:540]

258,New York: Queens - Woodhaven,"Woodhaven is a true melting pot with a mix of old-school locals and new arrivals. Parks, diverse restaurants, local bars, and community activities. Access to Forest Park is a plus, and value is strong.",Anonymous [web:547][web:555]

259,New York: Bronx - Woodlawn/Wakefield,"Woodlawn/Wakefield is suburban, green, and feels separate from the rest of the Bronx. Strong Irish-American and Caribbean communities, excellent delis, safe streets, and Metro-North access to Manhattan.",Anonymous [web:144]

Visiting the 9/11 Memorial is moving and essential.",Hugh [web:556][web:563]

262,New York: Manhattan - Yorkville East,"Yorkville East is friendly, relaxed, and now well-connected by the Second Ave Subway. Best for families, students, and anyone craving good bakeries, river views, and classic neighborhood charm on quieter streets.",Anonymous [web:561][web:570][web:574]
